The post Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org appeared first on The NuGet Blog.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[A11y Bug] Make TFM badges asset and compatible different for high contrast." (#9098) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
## Changes

* When high contrast, badges on table and on badge component now have border and font bolder.
* Compatible target bottom label now has a square icon with bolder border.

## Screenshots
The following are screenshot from different contrast themes on windows 11.

</details>

### Before

### After

</details>

## Addresses
https://github.com/nuget/engineering/issues/4347

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "MSBuild NuGet SDK Resolver fails to locate global.json file in Visual Studio project folder" (#11747) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, MSBuild.exe

### Product Version

Visual Studio 2022 17.2 Preview 3

### Worked before?

Visual Studio 2022 17.1 and earlier

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

The issue is a dotnet CLI template which contains a global.json file (in my case referencing a project SDK) which is then also used via the Visual Studio new project dialog. So the global.json file is in the same directory as the project, but in the Visual Studio case the default creation case is to create a solution folder and a project sub-folder. The project sub-folder contains the global.json file in this case. The MSBuild NuGet SDK Resolver fails to locate the global.json file in the project folder.

The issue was trigger by this [#4380](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/4380) I believe. There was a subsequent bug and a change with this [#4507](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/4507).

That secondary change almost fixes the issue for me, but unfortunately it does not handle the case when the resolver context defines both a solution and project. The existing [code](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/src/NuGet.Core/Microsoft.Build.NuGetSdkResolver/GlobalJsonReader.cs#L100) means the solution always wins even if the project is set. The consequence is that a global.json in the project folder is not found. I believe a change to check the project file path context first would resolve this problem.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: No way to suppress very noisy "The project ... is using CentralPackageVersionManagement, a NuGet preview feature."" (#11724) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

6.0.200

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

Every single project gets a warning about using CPVM as a preview feature in the console log. This adds a lot of noise and it would be nice to be able to suppress it. 

>  The project C:\git\VS-Platform\src\Editor\Text\Test\Unit\WpfView\WpfViewUnitTests.csproj is using CentralPackageVersionManagement, a NuGet preview feature.
  Restored C:\git\VS-Platform\src\Editor\Text\Impl\InvisibleCharacterTagger\InvisibleCharacterTagger.csproj (in 387 ms).
  The project C:\git\VS-Platform\src\Editor\Text\Impl\EditorPrimitives\EditorPrimitivesImpl.csproj is using CentralPackageVersionManagement, a NuGet preview feature.
  Restored C:\git\VS-Platform\src\Editor\Text\Test\Unit\CurrentLineHighlighter\CurrentLineHighlighterTests.csproj (in 2.03 sec).


### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Floating Versions in PM UI, define manual test cases for vendors " (#11453) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: With the implementation of Floating Versions, the behavior of the PM UI for installing/updating a package will change, that's why we need to update the manual test cases for our vendors so they know the new behavior and can test it to ensure there are no regressions on basic functionality.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: [ARM64] Command “nuget pack” cannot be run since could not load file or assembly 'C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Preview\MSBuild\Current\Bin\arm64\Microsoft.Build.dll'" (#11756) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

Dev\6.3.0.10

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

#### Device info
Device: Surface Pro X
System type: ARM-based 64bit processor
OS: Windows 11 Pro 21h2
#### Installation
1.Install Preinstall from: \vspreinstall\preinstall\preinstall.cmd
2.Install Visual Studio 2022 Dogfood build from: IntPreview Channel

#### Repro steps:
1.Create a Class Library (.NET Framework 4.8) in VS and build the solution. 
2.In the Developer Command Prompt for VS, create a nuspec file by executing command “nuget spec” 
3.Make an invalid image file (with txt format) and locate in the package. 
4.Add following to nuspec file  
```
<package> 
  <metadata> 
    ... 
    <icon>images\icon.txt</icon> 
    ... 
  </metadata> 
  <files> 
    ... 
    <file src="..\icon.txt" target="images\" /> 
    ... 
  </files> 
</package> 

```
5.Cd to the project path and pack the package by executing command “nuget pack ProjectName.csproj”. 
#### Expected:
Command “nuget pack” can be run successfully.

#### Actual:
Command “nuget pack” cannot be run since could not load file or assembly 'C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Preview\MSBuild\Current\Bin\arm64\Microsoft.Build.dll' as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632625/163803582-ffb9d020-f012-4758-8cad-f7484de943fe.png)

#### Note:
This issue does not repro with command “nuget spec”.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The tooltip of warning icon on the right of “Installed” tab only appeared for less than one second after installing a deprecated/vulnerable package in PM UI" (#11755) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

Dev\6.3.0.10

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Create a C# Console App (.NET core) project via VS.
2. Open PM UI of the project by right-clicking the project->Manage NuGet Packages… in Solution Explorer.
3. Select package source: Nuget.org
4. Search a deprecated package (e.g. “NuGet.Core”) and install it.
5. Go to “Installed” tab and hover on the warning icon.

## Expected
The tooltip of warning icon on the right of “Installed” tab appears for several seconds as below screenshot.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71433406/163773926-6ba8e66c-ac27-466c-9276-93e901c52a08.png)

## Actual: 
The tooltip of warning icon on the right of “Installed” tab only appeared for less than one second and then disappeared automatically as below video. It is hard to see the message on it.

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/71433406/163774032-4f20b3c5-74b8-4962-b604-4b729447286e.mp4




### Verbose Logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: Most SPDX license Expressions not resolved by https://licenses.nuget.org/ instead "We have no information regarding the 'Xyz' license."" (#11754) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe, Visual Studio Package Management UI

### Product Version

dotnet 

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

1. create a Visual Studio Project Nuget Package with an SPDX Expression e.g. <PackageLicenseExpression>Hippocratic-2.1</PackageLicenseExpression>
2. build, pack and push the Package using an Azure pipeline 
3. Visit the Package Feed / Artifact Page in Azure 
4. Search for the new Package 
5. Click the Project License Link in the bottom right Corner which links to https://licenses.nuget.org/Hippocratic-2.1 
6. Get an Error Message: We have no information regarding the 'Hippocratic-2.1' license. 

The https://spdx.org/licenses/ Page lists many licenses, 
but it seems only a few work, e.g. MIT, MIT-0, LGPL-2.0-only and MPL-1.0 

Many Licenses listed on https://spdx.org/licenses/  don't work and the link https://licenses.nuget.org/Hippocratic-2.1 displays a page with an error message reading "We have no information regarding the 'Hippocratic-2.1' license."

I understand that maintaining the full List is a lot of work, but it would be good to at least 
* include a Link to the SPDX License https://spdx.org/licenses/Hippocratic-2.1.html 
* or a Link the List https://spdx.org/licenses/ 
in the Message when it cannot be found on https://licenses.nuget.org  

Best Regards...

### Verbose Logs

```shell
https://licenses.nuget.org/Hippocratic-2.1 does not link to or mirror 
https://spdx.org/licenses/Hippocratic-2.1
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Test-SimpleBindingRedirectsClassLibraryReference fails against Dev17 with Exception message: Element not found. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x8002802B (TYPE_E_ELEMENTNOTFOUND))" (#10890) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The TYPE_E_ELEMENTNOTFOUND happens while adding a ProjectReference from the New-WebSite project to one of the New-ClassLibrary projects. The line is:

`Add-ProjectReference` $b $e

Disabling this test for now so we can proceed with the merge of release-6.0.x into dev.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Re-enable F# tests" (#11672) at NuGet/Home

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org" (#61) at NuGet/Announcements
